statement.title: Rolle's Theorem
Rolle's Theorem
statement.paragraphs: Let $f : [a, b] \longrightarrow\mathbb{R}$ be a function which is continuous on $[a, b]$ and differentiable on $(a, b)$ (i.e. $f'(x)$ exists for all $x \in (a, b)$). If $f(a) = f(b)$, then there exists $c \in (a, b)$ such that $f'(c) = 0$.

statement.title: Mean Value Theorem MVT
Mean Value Theorem (MVT)
statement.paragraphs: If a function $f : [a, b] \longrightarrow\mathbb{R}$ is continuous on $[a, b]$ and differentiable on $(a, b)$, then there exists $c \in (a, b)$ such that: \[ f'(c) = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a} \]

newcol.paragraphs: Let $f$ be a function which satisfies the conditions of the theorem. Define a function $g : [a, b] \longrightarrow\mathbb{R}$ as follows: \[ g(x) = f(x) - \left[\left(\frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}\right)(x - a) + f(a)\right], \quad x \in [a, b]. \] (Intuitively, $g$ is obtained from $f$ by subtracting from $f$ the line segment joining $(a, f(a))$ and $(b, f(b))$.) Observe that: \[ g(a) = g(b) = 0, \] so the function $g$ satisfies the conditions of Rolle's Theorem. Hence, there exists $c \in (a, b)$ such that: \[ 0 = g'(c) = f'(c) - \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}\,, \] which implies that $f'(c) = \dfrac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}$.

statement.paragraphs: Use the mean value theorem to prove that for $x>0$, \[ \frac{x}{1+x} < \ln(1+x) < x. \] Hence, deduce that for $x>0$, \[ \frac{1}{1+x} < \ln\left(1+\frac{1}{x}\right) < \frac{1}{x}\;. \]

newcol.paragraphs: We first show that: \[ \ln\left(1+x\right) < x\;. \] Consider the function: \[ f(x) = \ln\left(1+x\right) - x\;. \] Then, $f(0) = 0$, and $f'(x) = \dfrac{-x}{1 + x}$.

collapse.paragraphs: Hence, $f'(x) < 0$ for all $x > 0$.

For any $x > 0$, by the Mean Value Theorem we have: \[ \frac{f(x) - f(0)}{x - 0} = f'(c) \] for some $c \in (0, x)$. Since $c > 0$, we have $f'(c) < 0$, which implies that: \[ \frac{f(x) - f(0)}{x - 0} < 0. \]
Since $x > 0$, we conclude that $\ln(1 + x) - x = f(x) = f(x) - f(0) < 0$. We conclude that: \[ \ln(1 + x) < x, \] for all $x > 0$.
To show that $\frac{x}{1+x} < \ln(1+x)$, we proceed similarly.
Consider: \[ g(x) = \ln(1 + x) - \frac{x}{1 + x}. \]
Then, $g(0) = 0$, and: \[ \begin{split} g'(x) &= \frac{1}{1 + x} - \frac{(1 + x)1 - x(1)}{(1 + x)^2}\\ &= \frac{x}{(1 + x)^2}\\ & > 0 \end{split} \] for all $x > 0$.
Hence, for all $x > 0$, by the Mean Value Theorem we have: \[ \frac{g(x) - g(0)}{x - 0} = g'(c) > 0, \] where $c$ is some element which lies in $(0, x)$.
This shows that $\ln(1 + x) - \frac{x}{1 + x} = g(x) > 0$. Hence, \[ \ln(1 + x) > \frac{x}{1 + x} \] for $x > 0$.

Finally, for all $t> 0$, we have $\frac{1}{t} > 0$. Applying the inequality: \[ \frac{x}{1+x} < \ln(1+x) < x \] to $x = \frac{1}{t}$, we have: \[ \frac{1/t}{1+1/t} < \ln\left( 1+\frac{1}{t}\right) < \frac{1}{t}, \]
which is equivalent to: \[ \frac{1}{t + 1} < \ln\left( 1+\frac{1}{t}\right) < \frac{1}{t}. \]
